''[[A Gateway to Sindarin]]'' | subject=[[Varda]] }} "'''''Ir Ithil ammen Eruchín'''''" is the first line of a poem written by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] that was posthumously published in ''[[The Lays of Beleriand]]'' in [[1985]].{{LB|Song}}, p. 354 (lines 99-103) Though Tolkien never gave the poem a name, it is referred to by some people as '''[[Lúthien]]'s Song'''{{webcite|author=|articleurl=https://eldamo.org/content/words/word-3293589263.html|articlename=S. Lúthien’s Song|dated=|website=Eldamo|accessed=}}, a term first used by [[Patrick H. Wynne]], who analyzed the poem in [[1990]].[[Patrick H. Wynne|Patrick Wynne]], "Notes Towards a Translation of 'Lúthien’s Song'", in [[Vinyar Tengwar 9|''Vinyar Tengwar'', Number 9]], January 1990, pp. 8-11 The poem was also analyzed by [[David Salo]] in his [[2004]] book, ''[[A Gateway to Sindarin]]''.[[David Salo]], ''[[A Gateway to Sindarin]]'', pp. 211-3 == Poem == {| class="wikitable" |+ ![[Sindarin]] !Translation |- | Ir Ithil ammen Eruchín [[menel]]-vîr síla díriel si loth a galadh lasto dîn! A Hîr Annûn gilthoniel, le linnon im Tinúviel! | When the Moon, for us, the Children of Eru a heavenly jewel shines silver, having watched Here/now let flower and tree listen in silence/below! O Lord of the West, star-kindling, to thee I sing, I, the Nightingale! |} {{references}} [[Category:Poems in The Lays of Beleriand]] [[Category:Sindarin texts]]
